content:
{{knowledge objective
|Identifiant=OIC-347-07-A
|Item_parent=Acute urine retention
|Item_parent_short=Acute urine retention
|Rank=A
|Title=Knowing the initial assessment of urinary retention
|Description=None
|Rubric=Additional tests
|Contributors=Jonathan Olivier
|Order=7}}

* No further tests are required as a matter of urgency.
* If there is any doubt about the diagnosis, a suprapubic ultrasound may be performed to assess bladder fullness.

question.title: What is the next step in assessing urinary retention?
question.description: Based on the initial assessment, what additional test should be performed?

option_a.title: Imaging studies
option_a.description: Imaging studies such as X-rays or CT scans may be performed to assess the urinary tract.

option_b.title: Suprapubic ultrasound
option_b.description: A suprapubic ultrasound may be performed to assess bladder fullness and diagnose urinary retention.

option_c.title: Catheterization
option_c.description: Catheterization may be performed to relieve urinary retention, but it is not a diagnostic test.

option_d.title: Blood tests
option_d.description: Blood tests may be performed to rule out underlying medical conditions, but they are not a diagnostic test for urinary retention.

correct_option.title: A
correct_option.description: The correct answer is the option that describes the next step in assessing urinary retention.
